attributes.comment:
Dear USCIS,

This is in reference to the proposed increase in fees. I, and many other
immigrants that I know of, SUPPORT IT, for reasons that will become clear shortly.

----
ABSTRACT: A more efficient but slightly "costlier" immigration service immensely
benefits the common applicant, both because of timelier services, and also
because of elimination of the very expensive lawyers fees. The only parties
that lose from higher USCIS fees are the lawyers. These are the same lawyers
who organize a wide campaign of comments submitted to you opposing such fees.

----

Details: The current USCIS fees are completely dwarfed by the immense fees that
the typical immigrant pays to the lawyers. These low fees ensure a very
haphazard and timeconsuming service by USCIS. Because of that, one tiny mistake
can cause an immigrant many years of delay, or even denial of immigration benefits.

As a result of this, the immigrant feels compelled to hire lawyers, who tend to
be very expensive. Thus, the current "cheap" fees translate into very
expensive fees for the immigrant. The lawyers benefit immensely. The USCIS
loses because of a huge workload with no funding. The immigrant loses, BOTH
because of dismal service from USCIS, as well as due to paying immense fees to
lawyers.

A simple solution to all this is to make USCIS more efficient, by providing
funding for the process through raised fees. Because of increased efficiency,
the immigrant will feel less compelled to hire expensive lawyers. The immigrant
benefits both from increased efficiency, as well as save a lot of money. The
proposed increase in fees is completely dwarfed many, many times over by the
amount of money that would be saved if a lawyer did not have to by hired. USCIS
will benefit by becoming a more efficient agency that will be able to pay for
its own funding. The lawyers, the middlemen, will be increasingly "cut out."

The only "losers" in this new scenario are the lawyers. These same lawyers are
the ones who are aware of such news much more than immigrants and citizens are.
They organize massive campaigns, and encourage all their subscribers to oppose
USCIS fees. As a result, you will see a disproportionately large number of
"opposition" comments.

As you read them, I just want you to keep in mind that they represent the
viewpoint of the average lawyer, not the average immigrant.

The average immigrant pays thousands of dollars in lawyers' fees, and because of
USCIS's inefficiency, waits tens of years to see their loved ones, wastes
thousands more dollars in flights to and from back home, and wastes another
thousands of dollars in international phone calls made to loved ones. This
immigrant would love nothing more than a chance to shorten the above expensive,
agonizing and time-consuming process for the simple cost of a few scores of
extra dollars per application. He/she saves a lot of money in the process, so
the cost is offset many times over.

As an immigrant, I thank you for proposing an increase in fees, and hope to see
a more efficient USCIS in the process.



USCIS-2006-0044-0001
attributes.title: Comment Submitted By Abhinau Banguly
